author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Hey @everyone 

Please post your questions publicly on the Discord rather than DMing people privately

 I get the same questions over and over on DM here, on IG, even on Gearslutz. Which speakers? How should I treat my room? What limiter etc? If I were to answer each one individually it would 

A) Be a huge time suck
B) Deny everyone else that response if it was useful (including future members searching the archive)
C) Deny other contributors of the ability to build on that info, co-sign or even disagree so we can make our ideas better 

The working pros here give their time so they can have the maximum impact for younger players, asking for custom one off responses to your specific issue on a private channel undermines that

Thanks!

author: sinaigimenez
content:
Today I got a reminder of how important love and care are in what we do. Just wanna give a shoutout to @Nomograph Mastering for all the wisdom shared here on that topic.

Long story short — I agreed to mix a track for an American rapper who had already been turned down by some A-list mixers, even though the guy had a decent budget. The reason was kinda obvious: he’s got a personality that leans toward OCD, with everything that comes with that — defensive tone in convos, super long mix notes, and weird stuff like thinking a file sounds different just because it was renamed. (I forgot to label one file as “ref. limited” like the previous versions, and even though it was literally the exact same file, he swore the “non-limited” one had a different top end.)

Stuff like that made me seriously consider walking away from the project like the others did — I could just feel the back-and-forth drama coming. But after my first instinct, I remembered a lot of what’s been talked about here: love, care, and being open to the music and the art. So I decided to try empathy instead of just being a jerk out of frustration.

And honestly? It worked. After taking a bit of time to really talk to him and show I genuinely wanted to help — not just as a mixer, but as a human — I learned he’s totally burnt out and running on fumes 'cause he just became a dad. And I totally get that, since my first kid was born a month ago too. That connection shifted the whole vibe. The next round of notes actually made sense, and we ended up approving the first mix by version 4 — which isn’t bad at all. Happy client, job done.

Not saying you should hang onto toxic clients, but it was a solid reminder: don’t always go with your first reaction. Sometimes just showing a little care  about the person on the other side can change everything. It did for me this time. And tbh, I don’t think I would’ve handled it this way if I hadn’t read some of the stuff shared here. So thanks, y’all. This place is gold.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
...completely unrelated to anything  but on my mind this morning

Something I've said here (maybe too) often is that approaching the work in a loving way is a real unlock. Love being a quaity of a attention, a way of meeting things. It might not be obvious but it can start small and grow out embracing many more aspects of what we do

I mastered an album a few months back for a phenomenal indie artist, @Rob Domos and I both absolutely loved the music and the overall experience. The artist's team came back this week with a last minute request to remaster what was probably my favorite track with an added feature from a legacy artist. It's kind of mind bending how much better it is

Rob and I spent some time yesterday just appreciating that someone (the artist, manager, A&R?) actually thought up the idea of this feature and made it happen. I was so content with what it was but someone somewhere was like *"you know what would be sick ..."* and made it real. And now the world gets to receive something beyond what we could have imagined, something we didn't even know we needed

Just focussing our attention on that for 2 mins in the hall yesterday made the day better and put some gas in the tank. There are so many challenges in what we do, it really helps to take time to focus attention on the jewels strewn everywhere too. They are not always immediately obvious

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Ok Long Post alert, but touches on a few things we harp on around here. 

So my little bro is in town- we made dinner for one of his oldest friends who just moved to town with his wife. He’s a fantastic mandolin player and his wife is a singer/songwriter. 

Of course I did the ol’ studio walk through, listening to all the tunes on the ear calibration playlist, then let them play some of their own favs. Of course they’re blown away and have never heard music like this etc. 

But to drive the point home I show them a song @Rollmottle and I turned around in just over 24 hours. “The reason for the speakers & treatment etc is so we can make decisions quickly blah blah blah.”  I pull up the session and we listen through and they’re loving it- but I’m noticing it doesn’t have the 3D thing that all the other music we’ve been listening to has. 

Then I show them the mastered version. An mp3. It’s louder and better sounding and all, until the first BGV stack hits… then it’s IMMERSIVE. We listened to the whole thing again just to enjoy the magic and notice all the ways the master improved it. So far beyond zapping resonances and making it loud, @Rollmottle made it sound… important. Made *me* sound like a good mixer. 

It was heavier lifting for him cause I didn’t have the benefit of time for fresh ears or to detail the vocal the way I normally would. Also had the good fortune of having @Ross Fortune on speed dial and on GMT to give it a listen at 5am PST. 

I’d you’re curious, or dubious, I’ll DM files so you can hear what I’m talking about. 

TL;DR: monitoring matters, fresh perspective matters. Don’t produce mix *and* master your own shit.

author: NoahNeedleman
chrissorem
content:
Here is where we are at so far: O’Flaherty is known for his unorthodox and borderline mystical approach to mastering. While some engineers rely on meters, graphs, and measurable science, Ruairí prefers to keep things mysterious under the hood — very mysterious. No one really knows what’s going on in the session file… including Ruairí. And that’s the point.

Most of his day is spent clicking on vaguely psychedelic images of your waveform and nodding slowly. Sometimes he zooms in, sometimes he just stares at the phase scope like it owes him money. Occasionally, he’ll touch a knob — but never the same one twice.

author: NoahNeedleman
Nomograph Mastering
content:
Ok, here’s another perspective based on some recent experience

Classic scenario that’s played out a thousand times. “What do you do?” - I work in music. “Oh, what exactly?” - I’m a studio guy, a Mastering Engineer, I finish records. “Oh! Have you worked with anyone I’d know?”

For the longest time the answer to that question was NO. And so the question felt like “Are you somebody?”

But now I can answer Taylor Swift. *Everyone* knows Taylor…

But you know what’s happened? I realized that what they were asking all along is “Am I somebody?”

They are working changing my oil or whatever and looking for a little berry on the tree, or a shell on the beach. Something to take home that day, something to lift them up a little. “I met a guy who does XYZ today”. I do it all the time. My neighbor drives the Mars Rover. I mean, she goes to work, logs in and drives the fucking Mars Rover. And that is amazing. And being proximate to it makes me just a little more special in that silly human way

So, a little empathy for the shell gathering normies

author: Barbara
content:
Feeling like shite, scheduled an in person mix review, in order to finish this project - communication wasn't being effective, so I though it would be easier this way to get something that would make us both proud.
Got the dry files from the producer 1h before meeting with the band.

The project is finished on my side. On to mastering now. Today feels like the first day of my life 😆

All of this to say what I think is really important and some things I learned that I wish I knew when I was in the middle of those project blues:
1) you WILL get through it.
2) it might be possible to turn it down or pass it to another person
3) trust yourself and your skills to make the best you can
4) set boundaries and expectations. From the start. With the artist and yourself.
5) try to find something you can enjoy during the process - to me, it was on the very last day of mixing that I changed something on my workflow that got me excited, helped me get to the sound of the album we were looking for and will probably be something I will do for every project from now on
6) surround yourself from colleagues/friends who can help you - I know this needs a strike of luck too, but I'm sure if you don't have a reliable in-person "work friend" who can be there for you (with kindness, while keeping it real), this discord might be a good place to ask for that kind of help.

author: cian riordan
content: For mix work, I rarely do work-in-progress checks anymore. Although, I'll usually try and listening to mastering returns in Airpods or the car first to get a feel for how it sounds in the real world before geeking out in the studio. When I'm producing & mixing something, I'm often working on it over a longer stretch of time and find real value in listening to something in Airpods while on an airplane or driving around. Given how tuned in we can be as record-makers, I'm always amazed at how valuable passive listening is. I'm usually finding broad stroke adjustments that I can make down the road that really serve the project well.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Also, (having not looked into the details on Apple Classical yet) I think that could be a good idea. Classical music is an organizational nightmare right now on streaming services because classical music gets filed/classified way differently than pop music that has a single, definitive recording.

If I'm hunting for a recording of 'The Rite of Spring' there could be 40 different versions available to pick from. We need finer criteria to specify which version we're seeking. I need tools to search by the following: Piece name, movement, conductor, orchestra, year of recording, remastered/original, etc. The list goes on. Classical listeners need that level of granularity because the different recordings/interpretations are a big deal in the classical world.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
@Nomograph Mastering said a thing in #deleted-channel (go read it, it’s for everyone really) that resonated with another lesson I learned annoyingly late.

Ruarí: “For years I would open conversations by telling people how much I loved LA, and that I was here to learn. Shock horror a bunch of people opened up and taught me a bunch of shit”


My version in a sentence: “**Open mouths get fed.**”

If you want to learn something from someone, or you want a job, or whatever, or you’re engineering writing sessions when you really want to be writing - people will not guess these things. Get used to asking (respectfully, etc) and being clear about what you want, and more often than not (IME) people will be happy to help you, or send you in the right direction.

It won’t apply to everyone, but I wish I’d realised it way earlier.

author: Rollmottle
content: Many songs come out of the mixing stage sounding "done." Those songs could still benefit from perspective. I would not describe that as "a lot of the mastering processes happening in the mixing stage." For me, mastering is the process by which I 100% align the final product with the artistic intent. There's a technical component to that, but there's also a huge component of that that is pure vibe. Can I enhance the feeling of this song without getting in the way? Is the feeling of this song fully realized? Is the feeling of these songs together fully realized? Uncovering all that to me is the job. Sometimes it's already there and there's very little, if anything, to do. The perspective is still valuable. The key here is somebody who both understands the technical aspects of the job as well as somebody who can internalize and FEEL the music. The latter is why I believe mastering is one of the most misunderstood processes.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I'm totally with you on all this.

The question for me is less about the credit/ title, and more about the role. How do you get perspective at the end of the record making process? This role is changing, and we'd all be smart to understand where it's headed.

I get hired to finish songs a lot. Usually that means I have a "co-producer" credit. Sometimes it means "mixer" credit. Occasionally it's included "mastering." But really what I'm hired for is that combination of experience and technical knowledge. I'm an outside ear who knows how to fix what's missing. This role of "finisher" is really where a lot of the producer/ mixer/ mastering engineer profession is headed. The distinction between those roles is getting blurrier. 

Mixing engineers have moved from pulling up faders on the console and creating a mix (old school "mixers") to often just pulling up the rough mix of stems and making finishing touches (Jon, Manny, Serban, Tony, Bainz, etc.).

In this way, the "mixing engineer" profession is moving away from manipulating raw sounds to manipulating nearly finished mixes. This is sounding more and more like what a "mastering engineer" does. Now there's "stem mixing" and "stem mastering" too, further blurring the lines. These are all just slightly different configurations of the same thing. Who do you hire to get perspective and then act on it?

Those of us that are finishers or mixers or mastering engineers or whatever would be smart to think about how to adapt to the direction this is all headed. 

I want us all to win. I think we need to step back and expand how we think about the roles. It's the best way for us all to have careers.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: So right on this, to a T. It applies to emails and communication too. @cian riordan  and I had a convo about this recently. I used to sign off master emails with “I’ll wait for your notes/let me know if you need anything” or some variant.  Creating exactly the situation @Rollmottle describes. Now I sign off with “let me know how it feels”. I use Samply for streaming masters and have every single feedback and waveform option disabled. The goal is to make it as much like streaming on Spotify or Tidal as possible. I do artwork or an artist pic, i do proper song titles and not file names etc

author: BatMeckley
content: In all of this, as you pursue your passion, I’d say remember that what you’re great at might not be what you thought you’d be great at, or even what you’re working towards. I doubt Ruairi was a 12 year old dreaming of being the hot shit mastering engineer. I CERTAINLY didnt think I’d be a vocal producer, that gig didn’t even exist when I was a kid. The great music lawyer Donald Passman writes about how he got the “maybe the ‘music’ bit of ‘music business’ isn’t where your specific skill set resides” conversation and it changed his life for the better. Keep your head up while running down the court, you might see open lanes you weren’t expecting.

author: Rollmottle
content:
I have a career-level day job and have always viewed myself as an outsider as it relates to the industry. I have a deep passion and commitment to music and my day job allows me to pursue it the way I’ve always envisioned it. I am not in a position life-wise to financially struggle through finding my footing in the industry as a full-time pursuit, but I take it as seriously as if I had to. The practice of mastering, the way I envision it, is fucking expensive and my day job allows me to do it the way I see it. And like others, it allows me to choose the projects I wish to engage with and put out a quality product that aligns with my values. 

I struggle with imposter syndrome being an “outsider” but that’s never not been a thing for me as a creative. Just comes with the territory.

author: Rob Domos
content:
Had a great experience today of hearing records that I previously thought sounded bad sound great out in the world. 

You know those Latin dance records where the drums sound like icepicks? I went to a restaurant that was blasting that shit but it was coming from speakers that were installed in their tall ass ceilings so the treble was 90 degrees off axis and traveling far. Shit sounded amazing. Like perfectly balanced on some tracks. It made me wonder if that kind of speaker setup might be more common in Latin America and these engineers are balancing things correctly for their common venue playback.  

It’s got me questioning what I think I know and makes me want to get deeply acquainted with a wider variety of playback scenarios/environments.

author: Brian Reynolds
content: So I climbed into my 2010 Volvo S80 today. And for the first time in 2025. I was going to listen to my music on the speakers. I plugged in my usb c adapter. Into the coaxial cable that runs into the center console, for that true old analog gold plated warmth. Turned the windows and volume all the way up, then as I prepared to hit play. I was blanketed with the all to familar tension. That very same feeling from when I was going to have to sit next to one of the two dudes on the middle school basketball team. Who took as their daily task, to pay homage to ancestral animal social structures, by drowning any nearby male counter part with sack taps, donkey punches, and nail whip flicks. You just preemptively flinch at the inevitable pain from their onslaught. I hit play on a mix that is -5.8 lufs at peak. No proverbial donkey punch to my thighs this time. The song didn't overload the speakers at any point. As I heard the mix in my studio. I heard it here. The things I loved about it. I loved it here. The things I was unsure about. I was equally unsure about them here. My eyes welled up a bit with fulfillment and gratitude. It took me longer and cost more than I could of ever imagined, when I started this journey. But I got here. No longer do I have to worry about translation of the mix. I can focus all my worry on the feeling and vibe of the performace. I'm willing to let my ego have this one, this mix punches with any modern mix on earth. On any system. (Sounds killer on the Meta Ray Bans. And those speakers are rutheless honest. Ive heard alot of overloaded low end mixes on em) And back to the gratitude. I wanted to thank this place. I couldn't have done it without yall. I'd still be in a pitch black room looking for a switch that felt like it was hidden on the ceiling. Now back to work! Have a great day yall!!

author: cian riordan
content: I go back and forth. I finally got a decent turntable setup in the studio… calibrated, aligned, etc… and it was very interesting listening to analog and digital back to back. Most records I prefer the clarity and depth of digital, but there were a few (mostly from the 80s) where the analog pressing surpassed the digital. I still think the medium is a net positive in terms of music enjoyment and the collective industry, but I’ve moved beyond touting it as some sort of superior listening format. It’s just not. I remember mastering several records with Doug Sax and he would always joke with me saying, “you know there’s a better medium, right? Sounds better, is cheaper, etc”. Despite being the master, he understood how it’s evolved and had a sense of humor about it.

author: cian riordan
content: The TLDR is that the Colt guy posted a session with the mic on a snare and it was very clearly dynamically limited compared to the rest of the mics. Sam and a few other engineers brought it up and instead of listening or acknowledging something was strange, people got defensive and claimed that they couldnt hear or see the issue (including Colt and Darrel Thorp — who just engineered an advertisement video for them.) A rep from Lauten then chimed after all that and said that there was in fact a limiter built into the mic… which they don’t mention anywhere in the specs of the mic or any of the adverts. The mic could sound killer (the vid with Brad Wilk is awesome)… but engineers need to know what their tools are doing… and in this case, Lauten fucked the dog on that front.

author: cian riordan
content: Sonic consistency amongst songs on a record is one of those things that gets harder as you move further through the production processes. In an ideal world, you'd map out an aesthetic for a record in pre-production and make choices in recording & production to try and stay within those lines, whatever that means. A real world example I have is when I was doing the last Mini Mansions album, we locked onto a few H3000 patches that sort of defined how the drums and ambience would sound throughout the record. We obviously didn't use it on everything, but it helped thread the needle through a wildly diverse batch of songs. After that, having one person mix the whole album will undoubtedly help tie together a record that's been all over the map in production -- be it different styles or producers. As someone that often is tasked with doing this, I am always referencing other songs in the album to try and make sure things are sounding 'consistent'. By the time mastering comes, everything should sound 99% complete.

author: cian riordan

author: Rollmottle
content: this is certainly a take! i think i could make the same overrated argument about every part of the modern record making process other than the performance and songwriting. the job being "simple" doesn't make it any less vital to the process. after all, mixing is pretty simple too. 😉 i don't think  color-correction makes or breaks a film, but if done thoughtfully, it can certainly elevate what's already there, especially if the writing, performances and production are all dialed in. a lot of misconception around mastering comes because the other parts of the process AREN'T dialed in and expect mastering to do something it's not supposed to do.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
@Zack Hames while the business is certainly structured around this model, it doesn't really make sense for the future. "raw" tracks being handed to people is becoming a smaller and smaller part of the music industry. what that means is not that it's going to go away, but that it's going to consolidate. the future is the way pop and hip hop records are made (ps, it's actually the present and these two genres are hugely overlapping).

if mastering is now just hiring an additional expert mixing ear to subtly eq your two track, how long is that expense likely to last? not saying it's good or bad, it just seems obvious that it's a cost that will be cut

author: Rollmottle
content: haha...I'm a UX designer by trade and would have approached this problem differently. i don't know that we actually have a problem where we need a more structured and rigid way of soliciting feedback on music. maybe in certain high volume scenarios, i can see the use case. for mixing and mastering, putting an interface in front of somebody that makes a user think "oh shit, i can comment down to the every last second!" seems ripe for 1. woodshedding and focusing on things that in any other listening context wouldn't matter 2. makes me think I *have* to say something. as my client, i'd much rather you take the music wherever you feel most comfortable in whatever way you want to consume and just listen and then communicate back to me however you'd like without the pressure of a UI that might be unnatural to that workflow in front of you. it's a philosophical thing i suppose...i never want to add friction to your natural way of thinking about something, especially your own music.

author: spectrummasters
content: Hi, yes so......within the genres I’m most involved in currently hip/hop , drill and rnb the samples we choose and the patterns we create for these samples are all “trendy “ in a sense that it’s important in our genres to be seeking to present new sounds and patterns that others catch onto . This would be being the new wave . It’s vital in uk street music to be a creator of the wave / up on the new wave .....to garner attention . This dates back to jungle....where the producer/engineers were pioneering completely new sounds and rhythms via sampler technology midi and sampled breakbeats (amen , funky drummer etc ) . When a snare backbeat transitions from the use of a snare to instead a rimshot......or a particular clap sample.....and that track blows up, the wave moves . If you a year later release a track with the old snare on the backbeat instead of the rim .....that’s dated . The same goes for the other percussions, the bass sounds (eg 808 / Moog in intro/bridge combi ) .....and the patterns . So this is why In twelve months most of the productions these artists are dithering over , will be out of date. It’s just silly imo. Music is moving so fast and is ultimately so disposable at the mo holding onto it like some sort of special Tolkien esque ring is really just a vanity. Personally I’d venture this is also the essence of what makes pop music trends discernible . That’s just my opinion tho with respect to these genres. My overall goal is to record and mix work like rumours. Smokey , earthy and nourishing . A bit like @popaganda.  s last work .🙏🏼

author: kieronmenzies
content: Hey this has been a fun discussion to read through. Just to add one more angle to the mix: most of you have been referring to agency as some kind of positive trait that you either have or you don’t have it — almost commodifying it. What if we think of agency, or the qualities of having agency no matter what term we use, as the norm? As in EVERYONE has it. And whether or not we are able to fulfill those qualities and/or desires is due to limiting factors, whether they are external forces (class system, institutional racism, gender discrimination, war, peer pressure, financial hardship, lack of resources, etc) or internal struggles (fear, self-doubt, depression, addiction, laziness, inner saboteur, etc) or any combination thereof. I know it’s totally idealistic but maybe if we’re able to think of everyone as being just as capable as the next -- instead of an “either-you-got-it-or-you-don’t” kind of way, especially in terms of “agency” which sounds like a corporate buzzword du jour -- then we’d be able to focus on and address the aspects of our societal constructs and daily lives that restrict our opportunities to succeed/work/create/thrive/survive/exist.

author: hyanrarvey
content:
Yo speaking on what @Nomograph Mastering said a few days about staying cool…we have a producer in and so the whole room is a giant mess (like most studios are when they are locked out) and we sold an amp and we wanted to make profiles/name of it before it went out the door 

So the patchbay is a huge mess and I hooked up all the routing and wasn’t getting signal and I started to lose my cool and got super frustrated, Rick calmed me down and we worked out what problem was (I forgot I was feeding the the amp from the di multed on the patchbay instead of feeding it from the converter to run tones..) and after I got cooled down it clicked on why I wasnmt getting signal.



It’s extremely difficult to not get frustrated when trouble shooting and not get overwhelmed by a full patchbay but if you just take a second and breathe/calm down and start reversing your signal flow you’ll find the culprit and move on




Long story short as an engineer you gotta be the calmest one in the room

author: cian riordan
content: Currently going back and finding/prepping/printing mixes for mastering for a passion project i've worked on-and-off for over 8 years. Some are just printed WAVs from a long distant version of Pro Tools with plugins that don't exist. Luckily I had the foresight to print versions without my obscenely loud 2013 master chain. Some of more recent PT sessions open right up and play back perfectly. The real question is how much to fuck with them before sending them off. When is enough, enough? I've rocked some these mixes around town in my car for almost a decade. It almost feels wrong to mess with the mixes, but there's just so much that can be improved upon. Makes me realize how much of the work we do is emotional and not just technical. Sure, I could improve the low end on a mix, modernize it... but is it worth it?

author: Rollmottle
content: I'd pick one path and roll with it. As somebody's who's been at this crossroads (mixing & mastering vs. one or the other), I realized that to do one or the other the way I wanted to and do it right, I'd have to commit to one. And each of those paths imply different studio set ups and ergonomics and mindsets. I had 2 paths, you have 3. That’s a lot to ask of 1 space IMO. I don’t know how I could pull all of those disciplines off in the same space without feeling like I’m making a compromise somewhere. Tracking and mixing seem most compatible from a "one space" perspective. I bet focusing on tracking and mixing will be a relief and pay dividends for you. Your knowledge having done mastering before will be an asset to you in the tracking and mixing phase and make your end product even better.

author: Bonati12461
content: And sorry to bang on about this, but something that is critical to the audio quality on a record that is way out of most pro-audio people’s view is the state of the cutting lathe being used to do the master cut. Many people working in audio have never even seen such a machine. They are complicated - there are techs who work on consoles who won’t touch cutting lathes. IMO the best lathes were made by Neumann in the 70s/early 80s, and that was a long time ago. You have a TON of electronics and mechanics that need to be refurbished / restored to get the lathe to make some great cuts. Some engineers are cutting on some nicely restored systems and some are using some OLD stuff which should have been pulled for maintenance decades ago. Imagine if 50% of the records today were mastered on 50 year old loudspeakers with blown drivers and mismatched crossovers. We might notice.

author: austenballard
content:
I used to find when I worked on anything stoned I would end up over-focusing on one element, or making one thing WAY too loud, and also generally be slow. But weed never really agreed with me anyway, I gave it up years and years ago.

I kind of worry that any substance will negatively affect my hearing; there are some known negatives. Alcohol decreases your HF sensitivity, opioids disrupt level perception (to me, it always feels like everything I'm hearing is going into a slammed limiter) and stimulants like cocaine and amphetamines can (IIRC) reduce your sensitivity to loud sounds, putting you at risk of hearing damage

author: cian riordan
content: This is something where you need to figure out your own path. There are certain rules you can go by, but if you're just starting out, I would forego metering and start wrapping your head around some reference tracks. If you're able, have another track (that you know translates well) that's in stylistic ballpark of the song you're working on play out of a separate set of inputs. If you can toggle between your mix and the reference on a monitor controller, this is the best. There's a plugin called Metric AB that you can put on your master buss that will help as well. Then set the level of your reference track to 0dBFS so it's playing back full volume, and try and work your mix up to that level of 'loudness'. You're not necessarily trying to ape the sonic characteristics of the reference, but it will help guide you in making decisions throughout the mix process that add to the overall sense of volume. This will be much more insightful than chasing a single LUFS value or having a bunch of analyzers.

author: Slow Hand
content:
There was a bit of talk in #👩🍳mixing-talk where folks were describing how speaking on podcasts refined their ability to speak.

To keep the audio/speaking analogies rolling, I constantly remind myself that word choice and vocabulary are akin to dynamic range in speech.

Referring to everything as "fire" at one end of the emotional range, and "shit" on the other end is akin to making a hyper-compressed track that's sausaged at 6 LUFS. It's exciting initially, but diminishes in effectiveness over time if there is no contrast from moment to moment.

If you can use finer and finer gradations of meaning to make your point, then your words have more heft and more expression with which to make them. 

Check it out:

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Folks, anyone willing to jam on this? I'd welcome some perspective and am curious what others might think:

At times as a producer I feel that I have needed to become the 'artist by proxy'. At times as a mixer I feel I have needed to become the 'producer by proxy'. As well I could imagine how a mastering eng might feel they need become the 'mixer by proxy'. This language arises for me the more aware I am of what a 'great vision for a song', 'great production', 'great mix' *could* be and what it actually is in front of me. As well as from preconceptions of what the record making roles are about. I'm trying to connect the idea of a producer being someone who uncovers or brings forth an artist's vision (i.e. *"I saw the angel in the marble and carved until I set him free" - Michelangelo*) and someone who sometimes needs to manifest the vision when it is lacking.

author: Rollmottle
content: I've been a software designer for almost 25 years and still do it. Been running a label, making/releasing music and doing mixing and mastering for that whole time as well. About 3 years ago it clicked that mastering is my thing and decided to spend the last few years dialing in my rig and room around mastering. The job has been able to subsidize what has turned into a parallel career. I have designs on having this be my full time gig at some point, but I'm taking it slow, honing my craft and building my client base and studio while the steady paycheck is there. It's nice to be able to do that without grinding to make ends meet. I realize that is a privileged position to be in so I am grateful. With COVID, I can also crank out masters while I WFH when there's downtime or I need a work break. Some weeks are harder than others from a workload standpoint, but mastering is part of my brain-therapy so I'm happy to take it all on.

author: LAPhill
content:
Jumping in way late to this conversation, but some thoughts:

I'm broadly on board with @Rollmottle 's sentiments that no one is owed anything, especially in this line of work. That said, all music industry professionals, from mastering engineers to songwriters to musicians, increasingly are in a place where they need to prove why they're worth a premium cost. Premium is no longer newbie engineer vs. Serban, it's free plugins (or the artist's friend with a laptop full of cracked software) vs someone with reps at all. Maybe right now, the "premium" cost of engineering is minimum wage, but that is sadly still much more expensive than slapping CLA vocal and Ozone on your track with well-produced Splice loops. So why is your service worth more than that? It's an honest question that we all face.

I believe in the value of educating a client in why what we do costs what it does, but I'm not going to lose sleep over someone that can't see it. I see a ton of up-and-comers over valuing their worth and losing out on gigs because they don't understand how far they have to go. Engineers are often just as guilty at overvaluing themselves as artists are at undervaluing them. 

The one thing that does seem to still hold true in 2023 is that people that are doing consistently good work keep getting hired. And track records of reliability, decent (not even great!) work, and some credits that someone's heard of are all things to point to when talking about price. @Deleted User made a point of someone wanting him, but not seeing his value, and that's a particularly tough spot. Sometimes, you've just got to walk away from those people, as good as it feels to be in demand by someone.

send me a mix that isn't clipping the master bus.

author: Iwan Morgan
content: Absolutely @Nomograph Mastering i’ve got some perspective on this as I teach production and engineering as a visiting lecturer. The worst lectures (when I started) were just dense information with very little active element for the students. They had the info presented to them so that was learning, right? Of course, that was the wrong approach, and the more i’ve just provided broad themes to the group - i.e. make the sounds in front of you “angry, happy, distant, close” or “we will record/mix/master an EP within the next few weeks” the better the sessions go, and the more inquistive the students are to uncover the “learning” as they are doing.  I find making a fool of myself (“entertainment”) helps with this as it’s a useful tool to disarm the groups and build rapport. The more you can encourage students to learn from each other, and share the learning - prompted by me, the better the outcome is for everyone.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I’ve got a similar but different hack for A/B’ing between a reference on my Ableton template without the need for multiple outputs:

I drag my reference track or rough mix onto a muted *Reference* channel and set up a hotkey that does two things when I press it:

1) It solo’s the reference track and...

2) It bypasses all of the master buss processing on my master buss. So that the *Reference* isn’t being processed when I solo it.

Boom. Instant A/B referencing in Ableton.

i had my first mix mastered by Dale Becker recently and he made a great midrange adjustment and didn't touch the high end. obviously Jon talks about him a lot, so that co-sign plus my one experience will make me go to him more in the future.

author: cian riordan
content: The same way you can have a mixing perspective after recording. Or the same way you can have a recording perspective after writing. It's just a different process and you adjust your mindset accordingly. I agree that slapping a limiter on your mix isn't mastering. But plenty of mix (and recording engineers) have the skills and the equipment to create an adequate master for delivery. You may disagree with the quality of the work, sure. But to say it's not the 'correct' process I think is a blanket statement and just hasn't born true in my experience.

content:
Bob Katz’s *Mastering Audio* is a good way to fill any holes you may have in your knowledge of how digital audio works. 

I find *The Bruce Swedien Recording Method* to be something that I come back to year after year.

If you want to get very deep and nerdy Dave Moulton’s *Total Recording* is incredibly dense and will keep you busy unpacking it for years.

Books 1 and 3 are very technical, but I find the Bruce Swedien book strikes the right balance between technique and inspiring my musicality.

author: austenballard
content:
a number of years ago I consulted on a music tech curriculum for grades 10-12, these were some of the key points:

- Teach the fundamentals, always in a practical way. E.g. "Today we're going to record ourselves speaking" - briefly introduce how a microphone works, what a preamp is, and then get them recording each other. Same with EQ, Compressor, Reverb, Delay, etc.

- Use as many examples from current pop music as possible. Does someone in the class sing or rap? Have the students go through assembling a vocal chain with a compressor, EQ, etc. and record part of a song.

- Don't get too far in the weeds where it's not necessary. High schoolers DO need to know why we have different sample rates and bit depths. They DON'T need to know about aliasing, oversampling, clocking, or dither algorithms.

- Bring history in for context, but don't dwell on it. It's cool to know that we used to need a speaker in an echoey room or a giant metal plate to make a reverb, but focus on how and why they're using effects rather than where they came from

author: Slow Hand
content: I try to remove as many variables as possible. That means putting both files to be compared in the same program when I'm A/B'ing between them. I couldn't say why Pro Tools would be clipping your reference mix. Perhaps it's being processed through your master buss processing/limiter/etc. In that case you'd want to route your reference mix to a separate master fader with zero processing.

author: cian riordan
content: Not a full-time mastering engineer, but I have prepped plenty of masters for vinyl reproduction. Typically, I would try and find a way to bring down the level significantly without changing the sonics too much. This is usually as simple as peeling back the limiter. I'll usually deliver for vinyl around -16 LUFS. There's really no reason for it to be any louder. And as for the output on limiters (assuming you're talking about non-vinyl preparation), I set mine at -0.1 dBFS and if asked to deliver MFiT, will set to -0.8 dBFS.

author: Rollmottle
content: Not really.  I don't slam the limiter to begin with and I like to stick with 1 master to rule them all in most cases, so typically, the master is the master is the master. The cutting engineer can always turn it down and if the master is already dynamic, then there's not a lot of love lost. I park my limiter at -1.0 for all cases. There's still plenty of room to get extremely loud while allowing enough room to account for any encoding artifact weirdness.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
@David Fuller it seems like the Jon Castelli "finisher" role is going to encompass mastering at some point soon. everyone is already "mixing" as they produce and write (in the traditional sense of balancing and eq'ing and compressing). then someone like jon takes *the existing mix* and finishes it. the argument of having an experienced ear outside perspective is totally correct. that's what a mixer now is becoming. then from there a mastering engineer does... another even more subtle layer of sonic refinement but only to the 2 track bounce? and then decides how loud it will be? i get that this has some value, but based on the evolution of the technology and the roles of "mixers" these days, it seems like hiring a mastering engineer is going to become a luxury equivalent to hiring a second co-mixer or something. or getting real strings on a record or something. 

why spend the money if you already have one sonic finisher?

author: oaklandmatt
content:
i'm not actually quite saying that. i'm saying that most projects will only need one "outside ear" at the end of the process. mixer/ finisher/ mastering engineer will be one role rather than two. 

mastering used to be about technical knowledge for delivering different physical media. it was also nice to have one extra set of ears on a project after the tracking/mixing engineer (who was the same person from the 1930s to 1980s). but now we're going back to the tracking engineer and mixing engineer being the same person (possibly the producer and writer as well). there really only needs to be one more step. mixer/ mastering/ finishing gonna be the same role.

also fully agree that quality will continue to decline as more technically untrained people make music. 

btw i'm not arguing good or bad for any of this. just seems likely that's where we're headed

But as someone who has worn all the hats, (writer, singer, songwriter, composer, performer, producer, mixer, sideman, engineer, “artist,” music director, I’ve even mastered a few records,) I would say the work of any of these hands can be an art form in and of itself.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Couple of reasons:
1) it’s just easier to carry around, easier to pack, and doesn’t take up  a usb port which are at a premium on the mb pro.
2) I was working with a lot of producers that were just monster fast right off the trackpad on the actual laptop. There was a bit of “lemme see if I can do that” out of sheer boredom.
3) THEORETICALLY, the trackpad offers a higher ceiling than the trackball, especially with better touch tool. The way I worked on the trackball was using the buttons to swap through tools and it allowed me to work really really quick. The track pad has WAY more ways to chord and double/triple 2/3/4/5 finger tap/swipe to program oft used key commands. I’m giving it a year or two to become intuitive.

author: Zakhiggins
content:
What mastering really is, is someone with far more experience and reps than you in a highly calibrated room making sure your mix is definitely finished. If you’re just starting out, you probably don’t need it. If you’re looking for that last 5-10%, you probably do. Sometimes they don’t need to do anything other than tell you it’s done (which in my opinion is worth it) and sometimes they have to be more heavy handed. What they actually do (if they’re good) will likely be different every time. It’s about getting the song over the line, and whatever it takes to do that.
You can get plenty of great mastering engineers for 100 dollars or less. Reach out to some peeps on this discord and they’d be happy to help I’m sure

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
@Nomograph Mastering I actually had this same rabbit hole in my brain a few years ago, but it was watches not cars for me. 

While Rolex is an example of manipulated rarity, there are watch brands that ride this line, and honestly I think it’s a really close analog for what you do Rauirí. Guys like RW Smith make 10 watches a year, by hand, the quality is exquisite and they are EXPENSIVE. It scales up from there,  but I think there’s someone in that lane that probably hits all the markers you want to. 

Mastering is a necessity, but you can drive your moms Carolla or buy yourself a cybertruck etc…

You can use your phone to tell time, but where is the joy or passion for the art?

Seiko’s Spring Drive comes to mind. Using technology to  improve the art of timekeeping rather just trying to perfect it. 

Idk there’s obviously a breakdown in that watches are either good at telling time or not… but the how is fascinating to me.

author: Rollmottle
content:
Going to rep Tailscale here.

Been investing in some infrastructure and future planning over here. The problem I was trying to solve was making my working drive available to me for when I’m away from my studio so I can continue to be responsive to clients at all times. 

Tailscale allows you to create a secure, private VPN without having to have a networking PHD and compromising your network. Basically install the client on a device, 2-factor auth into the client and any other client you have installed on any device signed in with those same credentials are available to you as if you’re on the same local network, even if you’re on another network anywhere else in the world. It’s an actual game changer.

For a variety of reasons including keeping my mastering rig lean and clean and because the rig is not always on because I don’t want to run my HVAC 24/7, I sync a clone of my working drive from my mastering rig to a drive attached to an always-on Mac in my home network that has the Tailscale client authenticated. I’ve got screen share enabled on that Mac and now from any other device, I can sign into it and grab whatever I need from that clone drive. You can install the client on virtually any device including NAS’s and mobile phones so it opens up whole new avenues in how to think about availability of your data, traveling, 3rd party cloud vs. rolling your own, etc. Tons of possibilities. Really big fan. Love the future.

https://tailscale.com/

author: spectrummasters
content:
For me , LWMR sets itself apart because it never really struck me as claiming to be introducing some new ground breaking invention / product / idea …..but much more focused on understanding the origins and evolutions of good working practices and why . 

This resonated with me because , I really find myself thinking…..for all these new products like soothe / gullfoss / cla vocals / TGP ….and now stem splitters ….how much better do the records being made today sound / feel than those in the 70s ( for example ) . Like we came out of mono and into stereo and Jesus gains were made .!..for all the new clever software have we made those sorts of gains from it ? I think loudness techniques yes defo , but otherwise ? Hmmm . I feel like the best records today are being made by people who really know their engineering ish…..like LWMR was kinda all about imho . 

So it feels like a lot of the promo on “analogue emulations / stem splitters / multi band resonance tools “ …..although very clever ….kind of miss the point when it comes to becoming good at this mindfuck of mixing

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Skrillex currently has the hardest sonics (loudness plus emotion). For me, acoustic rock drums peaked in their excitement for me in the late 90s/ early 2000s era. Now the "hardest" rock drums are heavily augmented with samples because they otherwise can't compete in loudness with electronic music (see again: Skrillex, the rock guy who moved into electronic music for maximal sonic excitement).

Prob my favorite acoustic rock drums are on albums like Significant Other, Songs For The Deaf, Around the Fur, Audioslave, etc.

To me these drums **translate** the best. When you A/B against a Bring Me The Horizon record, they don't snap the same, but the room and depth I feels much heavier to me.

How do you handle mix notes where there isn’t one person that has the end say, it’s a group and each person in the group is only listening to their part of a song?

I’ve tried my best to relate how changing something on one track may make is sound like the other thing changed, for example a snare sound might mask tone of a guitar or saxophone?

Do ya just do the notes and try your best to make it sound as good  as you can?

Typically I might change something else when someone says saxophone up for example and I’m already near the ceiling, I’ll turn the other stuff down so that it sounds like the Sax was brought up.

I got notes to say saying “no changes” to every instrument on a mic BUT the drums, and they want the drums to “sound like” another song I mixed for them. I’ve put all the processing that I had on that mix on the drums, but it’s still not working, and it isn’t working for me in context of the rest of the instruments?

What would you do?

author: peterlabberton
content:
K, so, I’m not a mastering engineer, and I know that’s not exactly the focus of this group, but I’m curious to hear some of the most experienced folks on here (i.e. @cian riordan @oaklandmatt and I’m sure others I don’t know about!) chime in on loudness in 2021. For instance, I love love love Jaime by Brittany Howard, and Shawn is phenomenal (AND if shit sounds great who cares what the LUFS meter says), but it is loud as hell. With streaming theoretically leveling the playing field a bit, what are you guys looking for when you get a record mastered? Is there someone mastering right now who is just boldly NOT slamming a limiter and letting things breathe more? Do we care?

I ask partly because, like I think many people, I incorporate a limiter on my mix bus to get things loud and be mixing “into” a mastering chain, and this has led me down a bit of a rabbit hole.

author: Rollmottle
content: Mastering engineer here. Slamming a limiter is never my move. I will make your track as loud as it wants to be while retaining its intent and inherent dynamics. Nobody’s ever given me a dynamic mix and told me to make it less so….nobody’s ever given me a loud mix and told me to make it less so…point being, your intent will be baked into the mix and will determine how to approach the record.

author: oaklandmatt
content: I assume you've watched the hour we did on loudness? We might've done two actually...

author: oaklandmatt
content: the short answer to your question is that there is no standard. Each streaming service has a different loudness setting, and then even within that they each have different defaults of whether that feature is turned on or not. So if you make something nice and loud, it's going to be louder than less limited mixes if there's no normalization happening. But if normalization is happening (which again, is not only a different standard on each service, but may or may not be turned on) your limited mix is going to get turned down and your transients will sound like shit.

author: Eric Martin
content: all I know is it’s been around a lot longer and feels more accurate, AND Spotify/Apple/most normalization is RMS not LUFS, Apple has been normalizing since before LUFS was a thing and they use basically the same algorithms to do they’re normaling today that they used in 2001

author: David Fuller

author: Eric Martin
content: right, in a Lab testing facility, I think that MAYBE loudness should be tested in several environments, because we can handle wider variations in loudness in different environments, live music for example, how fast does the variation in loudness spike over time short-term versus momentary versus integrated, when someone says LUFS, the R-128 approved meters include ALL of those measures so a LUFS measure isn’t just one number it’s like 4 numbers

author: Zack Hames
content:
I’m pretty sure Spotify main normalization is set to -14 LUFS. 

In my experience with Broadcast, streaming, Advertisement audio, the LUFS standards have proven incredibly useful and quite reliable. Every project to do for “web” is mastered to -14LUFS, North American broadcast is -24, and Euro -23. Hulu, Roku, YouTube, etc all have their own little specifications for loudness. 

LUFS takes into account perceived loudness whereas RMS does not. It also does not measure or add to the loudness for passages of audio that fall below a certain level of loudness. So if something is far quieter, it doesn’t get factored into the average loudness.

author: Zack Hames
content: That all said, mastering records with an LUFS in mind seems kind of silly. There’s so much variety, and just because streaming is the standard now doesn’t mean it’s going to be the same standard in 5 years. It seems most people STILL master muchc much louder than they “need to”.

author: cian riordan

content:
I agree with matt that hiring a mastering engineer is a luxury in the present day tbh. Most of the records that I get to mix or produce I'm expected to deliver a finished product ready to release. However when a lot of things are at stake (label release) it's almost 100% sure that a mastering engineer will take care to finish the record, do some QC and especially keep a human touch to the art. Would a co-mixer be able to do that? possibly, depending on their skillset/experience.

with the use of AI and other systems the expense of hiring a mastering engineer is already fading away but only for projects that are less risky. Say, if you have a tape library of 500 symphonic recordings and need to submit it for streaming so a few folks can listen to it, labels will most likely get an automated system for that to make sure that the standard levels are ok and that it translates well. I'm sure there would be a hungry mastering engineer willing to get that done but the industry is past that era

FWIW at Abbey Road in the 50’s/60’s the new engineers started in the cutting room so that they learned exactly what was possible to put on the records as it was cut, then they gradually worked  their way back from cutting to working in the room with an artist.

I think this process is insanely valuable, I just did my first “true” tracking session in over a year and after mainly Mastering and Mixing for the last year/two my tracking mixes sounded dang finished.

author: peterlabberton

This Andrew Scheps podcast is fantastic. I’m not through this episode yet and I keep meaning to turn it off and get to work but, here I am, still at it. Highly recommended!

I was happy a few weeks ago to pick out a 16k tone ringing in a pretty big indie rock release that apparently never got caught in mixing or mastering. This was reassuring, but I know that I also definitely have a dip in the upper mids in my right ear—my guess is from years of drumming as a lefty, aka hihat on the right. In the last year or two I’ve always had a plug-in to flip left and right as the last step of my monitoring path that I can un-bypass to have a reality check. In addition to making sure there’s not an inappropriately loud guitar on the right, it’s just a great perspective shift.

For big clipper
-Push and Pull are the same sound, except you can also have output clipping when only using push if the signal exceeds 0dBFS after the soft clip process

author: cian riordan
content: Insight gives you A LOT of visual information that isn't really useful unless you know what you're looking for. I have two visual meters while I mix... a janky old Goldline RTA analyzer and a TC Electronics Clarity. The RTA is useful for quick visual cues of kick to snare balance, how subby something really is, or when I'm working out phase relationships between drum mics... I can quickly glance to help aid with decision making. It's not necessary for me to mix, but I've had it for 15 years and it helps me make certain technical decisions quicker. The Clarity is very useful for the loudness radar. I basically set a guide LUFS (in my case, I'm usually shooting for -9) and you get a great visual representation of where you're at over the course of the song. Its especially useful to avoid fader creep... where I might nail the dynamics and loudness in the earlier parts of the song, but might overlook the last chorus being significantly louder, and in some cases, more squashed than it needs to be. I'm also an LCR panning guy, and it has a 'balance-o-meter' feature that has a cool weighted algorithm for determining if your mix is leaning left or right.

author: andrew_yv
content:
An interesting side note re: the psychoacoustic HRTF binaural sound localization discussion from yesterday’s live with @Nomograph Mastering :

I can’t find my source right now but if/when I do I will link it, anyways… A study was conducted wherein moulds were cast of several people’s pinnae (outer ears), these were placed on dummy heads with microphones inside the ‘ear canals’ and recordings were made through each of sound coming from a variety of locations. Some of the subjects were audio professionals and some were lay people.
When the subjects listened back to these recordings, there was significant variance in their ability to localize the sound sources. If I remember correctly, they were generally better at listening through their own pinnae than others were, and audio professionals were a bit better at sound localization in general, particularly in the traditional stereo field. However, the really interesting finding was that there were some pinnae that were universally better or worse. People actually had improved localization through someone else’s pinnae than their own, implying that although we are adapted to our own pinnae, there are material differences that make some better than others for localization of sound.
This is all from memory of reading something a few months ago, so I apologize if there are details that aren’t 100% accurate, but I assure you that the surprising bit is correct!

HRTF-based binaural mixes are not exactly the same thing as dummy head recordings, but I wonder if, in the creation of the aforementioned “baller individual HRTF’s” there might be a place for some optimization beyond the exact copying of an individual’s unique acoustic properties.

I dont disagree with you that what you are both describing is true for where we are at currently and have been for some time. im trying (badly) to not promote my view as opposed to the views shared by the engineers in the discussion im referencing....but fwiw , in 2022 the global recording revenue i think was around 20 billion dollars. Im not a socialist....im not against the free market.......the discussion was centred around the growing leverage engineers have in the industry and whether that is being marketed effectively to increase the price of the skilled labour engineers provide. When i first started getting indie production deals i was adviesd in the music business, when it comes to discussing deals, everyone's friends...when it comes to paying on those deals......no-one's friends....its only business. author: Joshua Riley
content:
Been doing some searching of the Discord this afternoon but struggling to find much. 

I’d love to hear some wisdom on the generalist vs specialist topic

I’m personally just a mixer. Mostly pop music. A lot of my work is with producers or self produced artists and overseeing the final engineering of a project (mixing the track and then passing off to an ME)
I’m also one of the young ones so a lot of my connections that I make and work are through social media whether it be artists or producers. I don’t want to open a can of worms but I’m just finding so many people that are wearing the generalist hat (specifically from a producer standpoint). Seeing a lot of credits that involve one person Co-writing, producing, mixing and mastering a record or seeing a lot of productions where the mixer is completely bypassed because the prod & mix is done by the same person. Would just love to hear peoples opinions on the topic

author: Rob Domos
content: What’s your gripe with noiseshaped dither? I’ve heard you mention it a few times

author: Rob Domos
content: Also why is manny dithering anything?

author: Rob Domos
content: I can’t think of a reason to send something with dithering applied to a mastering engineer

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: The joke is that is doesn’t really matter. But if you are going to reduce bit depth, use dither, and stick with TPDF (triangular)

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Why dither? This is much explained online. Why avoid noise shaping? Because it doesn’t survive further DSP processing, can affect how we perceive frequency balance and attempts to solve problem that doesn’t really exist (dither being audible)

author: Rob Domos
content:
The idea that noise shaping can affect how we perceive frequency balance was my first thought for what your concern would be and I can get behind that. 

I’m curious about the statement that “it doesn’t survive further dsp processing”.

My thoughts are: while we typically don’t hear dither as a distinct thing that we can pick out and point to, we do hear the effects of it in the combined signal, and I subjectively feel like each sound in a record has slightly more defined separating edges without dither, and I sometimes subjectively like noise shaping for giving me more of that distinction between elements in the mids. 

(Not that it’s very applicable for me anymore because I stopped dithering 24bit exports about a year ago after some rounds of listening and chatting with a bunch of my friends in the EDM world about it and i’m usually delivering at 24)

author: Rob Domos
content: Not trying to go much deeper down a dither rabbit hole, just curious about what’s underneath your position

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I decided I disliked noise shaped dither years ago based purely on how it sounded and felt. Then reading Paul Frindle on the topic (one of the smartest to ever do it) there were some very esoteric technical reasons that supported what I’d heard. So I never thought about it again

author: Josh Bowman
content: Biggest thing for any post audio mix- find out the delivery specs before you mix it (ie broadcast or web only, surround or stereo or both) and setup your mix so your music, dialog, and sfx masters are doing any buss processing and leave your master/mix buss clean aside from final limiter. You wanna make sure the stems add up to the final mix exactly if possible to avoid future shenanigans. Label things very clearly. Otherwise just make it sound good! A lot of ad/agency people like the dialog pretty hot I find.  I’m actually not sure what OMV means. But I’ve been out of the ad mixing game for a few years so maybe I’m blanking. Did it full time briefly tho and delivered a bunch of network stuff so 🤷‍♂️

author: markmaclure
content:
That is 100% the answer it’s just really tricky to implement. I suppose you could filter out everything above the fundamental of the bass/mix/whatever and build parallel harmonics off that fundamental, but it gets tricky adding them back in without it getting phasey. You would also have to be very specific about which harmonics you add back in so they don’t stick out too much. 

This is super interesting to me because the fundamental that is perceived isn’t actually there! So it could have big potential for headroom/loudness if I could understand this better. 

However, I’m also hearing Ruari’s voice in my head asking me if this is worth the deep dive or if it’s just better to just use Rbass and get on with making songs haha

author: gatewoodsensei
content:
Very interesting question. 
#1 ). I’d lean moreso cutting edge to classic. But I’d give about a 7. I think the cutting edge stuff is what pushes society forward but you need to understand the *why* things were and are the way they are before you can actually begin moving things around. Kind of like coloring outside of the lines, one must first understand why the lines are there and what the lines represent. 

#2). I’m a 0 here in the beginning and then branching out in the later. I think it’s smart to become known for something and once you’ve established yourself, then branch out. Personally, I burned myself out trying to be everything to everyone. Trying to solve EVERY problem for every company limited my knowledge to fix niche problems in business thus limiting my income potential. 

#3). I go 10 easy. Long term success breeds *predictable* easy wins. I love the quote “it took me 10 years to become an overnight success”. Practicing a shot, riff, sales pitch, etc for years in the long term makes short term wins more sustainable and accessible.

author: Deleted User
content:
I loved the analysis, I had thoughts about a few points he mentioned. 

1. Paradox of climbing up to the highest level
Could Michael Jordan have become Michael Jordan if it wasn’t for the feeling of someone chasing behind him to become one of the greatest of all time? There is only one Michael Jordan, and can anyone else be that one and only without going through what he has put himself through? 

2. Acceptance vs Dissatisfaction
I think the dilemma here is between satisfaction and acceptance vs beating. I don’t think one or the other is necessarily the answer, but I think a good place to be is finding acceptance in where I am right now while still beating on myself to keep on improving to the highest level I could be. 

3. Potential
This is a crazy concept to me. Who is anyone to evaluate someone’s ceiling of improvement? Spider defined the meaning of ‘potential’ perfectly in my opinion. Not his exact works but; one’s capable/willing range of adaptation. Did the professor in Whiplash really expand his students’ potential in this sense? 

4. Abusive Internal voice 
I love how he saw the professor as our internal voice. And it made perfect sense to why I was so obsessed with this movie and the character. He was myself to me all along. I went back and forth over and over on whether this relationship was worth it to either of them. I think perhaps limited to this particular two people, because they had common goals/interests and made it happen. 

5. Joy?
I feel that this is the most simple and complex out of all things here. Can anyone NOT experience any frustration while trying to get better at something? If the answer is no, is there a way to better manage the frustration? 

Pursuit vs Result, our brain works the most consistently when we look towards pursuit. Result feels good but not for long, but what if the result meant more than just the goal being achieved? What if the “result” portion leads to another pursuit after another?

author: Matt Huber
content:
So, first of all, thanks to the buds here who appreciate what I’ve posted in the past.

Second of all, my thoughts on this:
 
I have a personal rule that I will NOT post anything that feels like EFFORT or out of a motivation to game the algo. If I’m “making content” and notice that I’m doing so out of a place that is less than genuine, I will just delete and move on. 

For me, the “mix tips” thing came out of a sincere place of excitement and passion. I would, as a growing mix engineer, stumble upon something that excited me, and I would find myself wanting to turn around to the people in the room to share…well, there’s almost never anyone in the room with me. So, I channeled that passion and excitement in a genuine way to share with the small community of mixers, mastering engineers and producers that I knew on IG. 

At the beginning of my career on to the middle of my career, that became a very fruitful source of business for me - people who followed me on IG, who enjoyed my posts, and began to view me as someone who MIGHT know a thing or two about mixing. 

As my career has developed and my clientele has growing, that has become less important, but it was absolutely pivotal in helping me build a deep bench of great clients, both indie and signed. 

But…I NEVER did it for that reason. It was always (and continues to be) a genuine result of my passion for what I do.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Thinking about REFs today on foot of a revision. Awesome artist, A list mixer. Has huge sine bass notes in a few sections that were chattering a bit with the short iZotope maximizer release. This mixer uses the same limiter setting on every mix and I copy it and work from non limited mix, sometimes tweaking slightly

So bass distortion sounds cool to me, but more importantly it was in the REF. So to my mind it’s cool and in the artist’s signpost of intention …. But they wanted it clean (which was possible and pretty easy)

I guess the message and the reason for putting it in general is that we’re all under the gun with deadlines, and all through the process there can be a sense of it’s just a demo, just a producer ref,. just a mix ref …. we’ll nail it later. But each girl or guy downstream is picking up on intentions from the REFs

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Reading a book right now called Unreasonable Hospitality, really great insight on this mindset. Balancing excellence in both the art side (cooking in the books case) and service side.

Have never understood the fear of what other people will think about how records we make sound. Rock and roll baby. Does the artist love it? If yes — that’s gonna be the stuff that goes out and connects in the world. And bonus how people will get onto our work.

Luckily (?) not being afflicted has truly given me an edge I think — both in the sense of being fearless about making moves (or not) and it seems people can almost sense it, even though it’s never articulated

I think knowing Ruairi before I started mastering really helped with this IMO as well

author: spectrummasters
content: I just spent a month abroad prepping / basic balancing /eqing mixes on earbuds . I forbade myself from doing anything to the low end at all until I got back to my speakers . It worked out well . I’m v happy with the headphone decisions . However , I judge my low end  entirely by feel in the room though , the physical stimulation I feel guides me . A while back we discussed here in reference to a podcast I believe  ruairi posted , about using feel in mixing . I’m interested if anyone here has a particular vision about how one can compensate for or say goodbye to that specific aspect of sound (the feel ) and how useful it is in record making . I think of drums and bass particularly in terms of the frequency ranges and how the transients feel on my ears / chest / belly etc for the different parts. Any vision on how headphones mixing : mastering can satisfy this

author: samvalentine
content:
Hey, I’m not sure where to post this exactly, but I had an interesting experience the other day that I’d like to share with the group and hopefully get some perspective on.

I was touching up a track with a producer friend at the end of a writing session. Vocals and guitar recorded over a 2track beat. I typically throw a Waves L2 on my master, just to bring up the level for the rough bounce, never doing much more than a dB or two of gain reduction. In this case I had the threshold of the L2 set at -3.4. The producer said try -3.5, then back to -3.4, then -3.5… flipping back and forth seeing what he liked more. I couldn’t hear a difference. (I should say that we weren’t in a well treated room, working on some mid sized genelecs. It’s a  setup neither of us is super familiar with.) He decided -3.4 was better and I was in disbelief that he could even hear a difference. I asked if I could do a blind test to see if he could tell which setting was which. He closed his eyes and I switched back and forth a bunch of times before landing on a setting, and he called it correct three times in a row. He said he could hear something in the kick drum but couldn’t explain more than that.
I need a sanity check. I know my ears aren’t hall of fame, but I’m still in disbelief that he was able to tell a .1dB difference in volume on the limiter.

author: Josh
content: I too am skeptical but there is something specifically with kick drums and bass that I find there’s a hard point of difference with limiters.

I had an artist I felt was limiting our results because he insisted he loved my shitty first draft of the production and it felt like he didn’t even want to hear my ideas past a certain point. Hence the rushedness you said you’ve witnessed, an urgency to get ideas in before demo-itis solidifies.

author: kylem
content: I’m dealing with some artist / producer / mastering approval bs at the moment. Artist approved master, producer has notes. Fine. Producer has more notes. Fine. Master finally approved. 2 weeks later, artist reaches out and says he wants the lead vocal a lot darker. I do the revision, he’s happy. We re-send to mastering and artist asks me to pull producer off CC…I’ve dealt with this before, but the producer has specifically asked me multiple times to make sure HE gets his word in before the artist approves masters. At the end of the day, it's the artists song and I want him to be happy, but I know the producer is going to be pissed when he hears it out in the world and immediately text me. Not sure what the answer is. Feel like it's lose-lose. But maybe not? Would love to hear what other people do in these situations

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻
content:
Today I had a „damn“ moment

Super young artist I‘m working with (produced and mixed a song for him)  said „I can’t hear a significant difference between the master your guy did and this AI master. Can we cancel working with the mastering engineer?“

I ended up having a talk with him and he came around wanting to use the „human“ master instead after listening a couple more times and indeed noticing some improvements over the AI one. I also explained to him the benefit of included revisions included in the rate for the master.

Some of this comes down to him being a bit more inexperienced, though I still found the casualness in the way he suggested using the AI one and simply ditching the human engineer a bit shocking and also quite frankly scary

I wonder if this an isolated incident or something I‘ll have to discuss with younger Artists in the future time and time again

(Just to be clear, I didn‘t even say that it‘s a downright must to use the human version if he prefers the AI one. I just made it clear to him that the human engineer still has to be paid regardless) 

did you guys have a similar experience lately? How did you react?

(If this is more appropriate for #🎚mastering-talk or #🤖ai-talk lmk)

Confession that I have the Landr plugin as part of a final step where I A/B my master chain with what Landr did by itself to make sure I’m making something that I feel is better than what woulda been done in 2 seconds with their automated service.

I say confession because I feel like a jerk in how I’m using the plugin as a ‘lowest benchmark’ check which feels mean spirited towards Landr, but I find A/Bing useful to compare the great mixes I’m striving for, as well as the low hanging fruit that I’m striving to blow out of the water.
